currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion,

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea.

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 


 think we should adopt the Australian model of paying college athletes.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 

 think we should adopt the Australian model of paying college athletes.
 In Australia, every university and college athlete that makes the team is paid and given a scholarship. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds.

currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 

 think we should adopt the Australian model of paying college athletes.
 In Australia, every university and college athlete that makes the team is paid and given a scholarship. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room

currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service the University of Tennessee implements.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service the University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service the University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service the University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams.

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service thatthe University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the University of Tennessee's football program.
 The university benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 



If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias football program.
 The universities benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the University of Tennessee implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefits from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Aust implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Athletes can gain endorsement m

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played.

If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education.

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played.

If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education.

 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popular

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of the

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore. 

It would be advantageous to pay our athletes, to re

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore. 

It would be advantageous to pay our athletes, to repay them for their efforts

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore. 

It would be advantageous to pay our athletes, to repay them for their efforts, and to give them more opportunities.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.

Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore. 

It would be advantageous to pay our athletes, to repay them for their efforts, and to give them more opportunities.  It's time we overhauled the system and f

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, paying college athletes is an excellent idea. 
For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played. 
The best example to use in terms of the advantages of paying college players is the UAustralias fsoccerpand rugby rogram.s. The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore. 

It would be advantageous to pay our athletes, to repay them for their efforts, and to give them more opportunities.  It's time we overhauled the system and followed the suit of other countries in

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

For one, I think it would help provide a more stable future for many student-athletes.
 It is well-known that a good amount of student athletes don't go on to play for the pros after college, and those that do, aren't guaranteed a very high salary or even a job in the field they played.

The universities benefit from their players in promos, ticket sales, and other perks that allow the school to generate positive funds. Students who are lucky enough to be a part of the team can receive just about anything they ask for off the field and still receive free tuition, room, board, and the opportunity to be on a university team. If a player gets injured, that player is also provided with insurance, along with a stipend for their education. 

Athletes can gain endorsement money, and do advertising for companies. They can capitalize on the popularity of their images, and their place on the school's team. 

If this same system were implemented in the United States, many colleges would be able to provide the same service that the Australia implements. ot only does paying college athletes create a more stable future for student-athletes, but it also creates a more fair society where those
 who make the most money for their schools, get the most amount of money back from their schools. 

College sports can also be seen as a leveler, where kids who couldn't afford to play for professional teams would have an opportunity to play for prestigious college teams. If college athletes were paid, it could lead to all kinds of new talent for universities and professional sports teams, which would be very difficult to ignore.
